verses.text: Have mercy on us, Lord of all, and look upon us,
verses.comment: Sirach begins this prayer seeking God's mercy, a theme central to the wisdom literature and echoed in Psalm 123. The address to the 'Lord of all' emphasizes God's sovereignty over every nation and individual.

verses.text: Send your fear upon all the nations who do not know you;
verses.comment: The author asks God to reveal His power to non-believing peoples, similar to the prayers in the Psalms. There's a desire for universal acknowledgment of God's majesty.

verses.text: Lift your hand against foreign nations, so that they may see your might.
verses.comment: God's intervention among the nations displays His glory and sets up the expectation of future judgment. This echoes Exodus, as God made His power known to Egypt and others.

verses.text: Just as you have shown them your holiness in us, so now show your glory in them.
verses.comment: Here, the author begs God for equal manifestation of His glory in the Gentiles as He had shown among His chosen people. This foreshadows the extending of salvation to all nations.

verses.text: Let them come to know you, just as we have come to know you, that there is no God but you, O Lord.
verses.comment: The acknowledgment of monotheism stresses deep Jewish faith and provides an early seed for universal worship, hinting at the later worldwide spread of faith through the gospel.

verses.text: Renew signs and repeat wonders;
verses.comment: Asking God to do great deeds as in the days of old, and anticipate miracles accompanying the way God works in both Old and New Testament times. Connects to the signs God performed both in Exodus and through Christ.

verses.text: Glorify your hand and your right arm so that they may experience your wonders.
verses.comment: The imagery of God's right hand signifies power and victory, foreshadowing how Christ is described as seated at God's right hand (see Hebrews 1:3).

verses.text: Pour out your anger on nations that have not known you, and on kingdoms that have not called on your name.
verses.comment: The idea of divine judgment is a consistent theme. Note the spiritual implication: even today, praying for justice but also for the conversion of those far from God.

verses.text: For they have devoured Jacob and desolated his homeland.
verses.comment: This verse refers to enemies of Israel who have oppressed God's people—pointing to the need for restoration and justice.

verses.text: Do to them as you did to Midian, to Sisera and Jabin at the river Kishon;
verses.comment: The prayer recalls past military victories. This invocation of historical acts reminds believers of God's continued power to save and judge.

verses.text: They were destroyed together in their pride and turned to shame.
verses.comment: The defeat of proud oppressors echoes the theme of God humbling those who exalt themselves. Shame comes as a consequence of wickedness.

verses.text: Scatter their leaders and break the power of their rulers.
verses.comment: God's sovereignty over rulers is a key biblical idea. This verse asks God to overthrow worldly powers that oppose Him.

verses.text: Let those who survive be consumed by terror, and let their power collapse.
verses.comment: A continuation of the prayer for justice, drawing on Torah traditions of curses upon the unrighteous nations.

verses.text: Crush those who oppress us with violence, so they may know there is no one but you who defends your people.
verses.comment: This verse points to an exclusivity of God's protection for His people, and hints at spiritual warfare—an idea central to later Christian prayer.

verses.text: Shower mercy upon your people whom you have called by your name, O Lord.
verses.comment: There is an emphasis on God's chosen people, echoing both the Abrahamic calling and the later idea of the church as God's own.

verses.text: Show your compassion to your sanctuary, and let Jerusalem be filled with your glory.
verses.comment: This prayer for the sanctuary points to the centrality of worship and God dwelling among His people. See Ezekiel’s promise of glory returning to God's house—parallels later fulfillment in Christ.

verses.text: Testify to those whom you created at the beginning, and fulfill the prophecies spoken in your name.
verses.comment: God’s promises and prophecies are assured; the call for fulfillment connects OT prophecies to New Testament fulfillment in Jesus.

verses.text: Give reward to those who wait for you, and let your prophets be found trustworthy.
verses.comment: Emphasizes faithfulness and patience, themes important for prophetic ministry and Christian perseverance.

verses.text: Hear the prayer of your servants according to the blessing of Aaron on your people.
verses.comment: A direct reference to the priestly blessing, indicating the continued importance of priestly intercession and mediation—see Numbers 6. The spiritual implication is that blessings come through a sacred ordering.

verses.text: May all the people on earth recognize that you are the Lord, the eternal God.
verses.comment: The prayer is for universal worship—echoes messianic prophecies of God's name being known among all nations, a recurring theme in both testaments.

verses.text: The stomach can take any food, but one food is better than another.
verses.comment: Beginning a wisdom section, with parallels to Proverbs and food laws, symbolically contrasting spiritual nourishment and wisdom.

verses.text: As the palate tastes different kinds of food, so does a discerning mind detect false words.
verses.comment: Natural sense is likened to spiritual discernment—see Job's analogy.

verses.text: A woman's heart can sometimes shape her husband, so it is with a discerning woman who finds rest for her husband.
verses.comment: Here, the text highlights the role of women in marriage, blending ancient wisdom with family instruction.

verses.text: A wife can be taken for her appearance, but her value is in her heart and her hands.
verses.comment: The biblical idea that inner qualities outweigh physical beauty is repeated in Scripture, especially in the wisdom tradition.

verses.text: If her tongue brings healing and kindness, her husband is not like other men.
verses.comment: Suggests that a wise and gracious wife elevates her husband above others, creating an ideal image of spiritual partnership.

verses.text: He who acquires a wife begins to possess riches—a helper matching him, a strong pillar.
verses.comment: Marriage is highlighted as a source of spiritual and earthly blessing (Genesis 2), echoing the partnership God instituted at creation.

verses.text: Where no wall surrounds, property is left unprotected; so a man without a wife is anxious and wandering.
verses.comment: The comparison draws a parallel between the safety given by a wall and the stability provided by a wife, presenting marriage as a safeguard.

verses.text: Who will trust a well-fitted thief who quickly wanders from city to city?
verses.comment: The warning here emphasizes discernment and trustworthiness, paralleling the wisdom against trusting unreliable people.

verses.text: So also with a man who has no nest, who lodges wherever night finds him.
verses.comment: Compares a homeless man to a bird without a nest, underscoring the value of family, stability and rootedness—seen again in Christ's reference to Himself (Matt 8:20).

verses.text: The decision to settle down brings peace and order to a man’s life.
verses.comment: Peace and stability are linked to wise living and family—a spiritual reflection of God’s design for community and fruitful life.

verses.text: So it is with wisdom: she builds her house and preserves her children for generations.
verses.comment: The wisdom tradition culminates in the imagery of wisdom as the builder and sustainer—a deeper allegory for the church and the communion of saints extending across generations. The spiritual reading points forward to the later development of the people of God united in faith and truth.
